perturbation.original_text: (b) Disagreements; Attorneys' Fees. The parties agree to attempt to resolve any disputes, controversies or claims ("Dispute") arising out of or relating to this Agreement in a meeting between a representative of each party who has decision-making authority with respect to a Dispute. Should the meeting either not take place or not result in a resolution of the Dispute within thirty (30) days following notice of the Dispute to the other party, then either party may bring suit or action in accordance with this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: (b) Disagreements; Attorneys' Fees. The parties agree to attempt to resolve any disputes, controversies or claims ("Dispute") arising out of or relating to this Agreement in a meeting between a representative of each party who has decision-making authority with respect to a Dispute. Should the meeting either not take place or not result in a resolution of the Dispute within ten (10) days following notice of the Dispute to the other party, then either party may bring suit or action in accordance with this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates a 30-day negotiation period before initiating a lawsuit. Shortening this to 10 days could be considered an unreasonably short time frame for mandatory pre-litigation negotiation, especially in complex business disputes. While California law doesn't explicitly mandate a specific negotiation period, courts often look unfavorably on contractual terms that severely limit a party's ability to reasonably address disputes before resorting to litigation, especially in cases involving potential power imbalances.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially conflicts with California's implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, which requires parties to act reasonably in fulfilling their contractual obligations. An unreasonably short negotiation period could be seen as a violation of this covenant.

perturbation.original_text: 6. Non-Solicitation. Consultant will not, during the Term, and for a period of one (1) year thereafter, directly or indirectly: (i) solicit, recruit or promote the solicitation or recruitment of any employee or consultant of the Company for the purpose of encouraging that employee or consultant to leave the Company's employ or sever an agreement for services; or (ii) solicit, participate in or promote the solicitation of any of the Company's clients, customers, or prospective customers with whom Consultant had a Material Contact (hereinafter defined) and/or regarding whom Consultant received Confidential Information, for the purpose of providing products or services ("Competitive Products/Services").
perturbation.changed_text: 6. Non-Solicitation. Consultant will not, during the Term, and for a period of two (2) years thereafter, directly or indirectly: (i) solicit, recruit or promote the solicitation or recruitment of any employee or consultant of the Company for the purpose of encouraging that employee or consultant to leave the Company's employ or sever an agreement for services; or (ii) solicit, participate in or promote the solicitation of any of the Company's clients, customers, or prospective customers with whom Consultant had a Material Contact (hereinafter defined) and/or regarding whom Consultant received Confidential Information, for the purpose of providing products or services ("Competitive Products/Services").
perturbation.explanation: California law generally disfavors non-compete agreements, and while non-solicitation clauses are more readily enforceable, a two-year restriction could be deemed unreasonable in scope, especially considering the nature of the consulting services. California Business and Professions Code Section 16600 generally prohibits contracts that restrain a person from engaging in a lawful profession, trade, or business.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Business and Professions Code Section 16600

perturbation.original_text: 3. Termination. Either party may terminate this agreement after 3 years following the effective date. (a) In addition, this Agreement will terminate upon the following: (1) Completion of work or period of work provided in this agreement. (2) Termination by Company or Consultant for any material breach, which is not cured within 30 days after written notice of any such material breach from the non-breaching party, pursuant to the terms of the Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: 3. Termination. Either party may terminate this agreement after 5 years following the effective date. (a) In addition, this Agreement will terminate upon the following: (1) Completion of work or period of work provided in this agreement. (2) Termination by Company only for any material breach, which is not cured within 10 days after written notice of any such material breach from the non-breaching party, pursuant to the terms of the Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: Extending the minimum term to 5 years may be considered unreasonably long given the nature of the agreement. Reducing the cure period to 10 days only available to the company provides consultant with less time to remedy the breach and could be considered unconscionable, potentially running afoul of California contract law principles emphasizing fairness and reasonableness.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially conflicts with California's requirements for fair and reasonable contract terms, particularly in situations where there may be a power imbalance between the parties.
